On Aug. 8, 2017, Roma Laster, a Pentagon employee responsible for policing conflicts of interest, emailed an urgent warning to the chief of staff of then-Secretary of Defense James Mattis. Several department employees had arranged for Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon, to be sworn into an influential Pentagon advisory board despite the fact that, in the year since he‚Äôd been nominated, Bezos had never completed a required background check to obtain a security clearance.

Mattis was about to fly to the West Coast, where he would personally swear Bezos in at Amazon‚Äôs headquarters before moving on to meetings with executives from Google and Apple. Soon phone calls and emails began bouncing around the Pentagon. Security clearances are no trivial matter to defense officials; they exist to ensure that people with access to sensitive information aren‚Äôt, say, vulnerable to blackmail and don‚Äôt have conflicts of interest. Laster also contended that it was a ‚Äúnoteworthy exception‚Äù for Mattis to perform the ceremony. Secretaries of defense, she wrote, don‚Äôt hold swearing-in events.

Laster‚Äôs alarms triggered fear among Pentagon brass that Mattis would be seen as doing a special favor for Bezos, which could put him in hot water with President Donald Trump, who has repeatedly proclaimed his antipathy to Bezos, mainly because of his ownership of The Washington Post. The swearing-in was canceled only hours before it was scheduled to occur. (This episode, never previously reported, is based on interviews with six people familiar with the matter. An Amazon spokesperson said the company was told that Bezos did not need a security clearance and that the company provided all requested information.) Laster did her best to enforce the rules. She would challenge the Pentagon‚Äôs cozy relationship not only with Bezos, but with Google‚Äôs Eric Schmidt, the chairman of the defense board that Bezos sought to join. The ultimate resolution? Laster was shunted aside. She was removed from the innovation board in November 2017 (but remains at the Defense Department). ‚ÄúRoma was removed because she insisted on them following the rules,‚Äù said a former DOD official knowledgeable about her situation.

This month, the Trump White House unveiled a new policy it had aggressively pushed through the regulatory process that makes it much harder for low-income immigrants, especially those who had used public benefits, to come to or remain in the United States.

The proposal ‚Äî known as the ‚Äúpublic charge‚Äù rule, since it creates a complicated test to determine whether an immigrant is ‚Äúlikely to be a public charge‚Äù ‚Äî has the potential to dramatically restrict who‚Äôs allowed to settle in the country. And many people who work with immigrants, including social service providers and local and state governments, are worried that it will scare them away from using benefits they and their families need to thrive.

To soften the blow, the rule contains a few exceptions ‚Äî groups of immigrants who are allowed to use public benefits without jeopardizing their future immigration status. But the rule is so sloppily written that it ended up treating immigrants who are married to U.S. citizens more harshly than immigrants married to noncitizens.

Active-duty service members who are immigrant noncitizens are allowed to use benefits without having it weigh against them as a ‚Äúpublic charge‚Äù in the future. So are the family members of active-duty immigrant service members. But immigrants who are the spouses or children of active-duty service members who are U.S. citizens are not included in the exception, meaning their use of benefits while their spouses were on active duty could jeopardize their future in the U.S. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sloppy drafting. They‚Äôre trying to get the regulation out sooner than is probably practical,‚Äù said Charles Wheeler, an immigration attorney at the Catholic Legal Immigration Network, Inc.

A spokeswoman for U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, the agency that developed and is implementing the rule, declined to comment because of pending litigation against the regulation.

Three University of Mississippi students have been suspended from the Kappa Alpha fraternity and face possible investigation by the Department of Justice after posing with guns in front of a bullet-riddled sign honoring slain civil rights icon Emmett Till.

The photo was posted on Ben LeClere‚Äôs private Instagram account in March and obtained by ProPublica and the Mississippi Center for Investigative Reporting.

LeClere is on the left holding a shot gun. His fraternity brother, John Lowe, squats below the sign.

This is a letter Melvin Davis wrote on his 91st day behind bars for refusing to leave land his family had owned since one generation after the end of slavery.

He and his brother, Licurtis, had been convicted of no crime, but ultimately spent eight years in jail.

Their land was something called heirs‚Äô property‚Äîland handed down without a will‚Äî that‚Äôs estimated to make up more than a third of Southern black-owned land.

A legal loophole means that there‚Äôs little that they can do to prevent its sale ‚Äî and the brothers aren‚Äôt the only ones to pay the price. In the past century,  black families have lost an estimated 700 billion dollars in land.

Read the full story on ProPublica.org

Like the system of wealth-based detention they are meant to help reform, ankle monitors often place poor people in special jeopardy. Across the country, defendants who *have not been convicted of a crime* are put on ‚Äúoffender funded‚Äù payment plans for monitors that sometimes cost more than their bail. And unlike bail, they don‚Äôt get the payment back, even if they‚Äôre found innocent. 
Although a federal survey shows that nearly 40% of Americans would have trouble finding $400 to cover an emergency, companies and courts routinely threaten to lock up defendants if they fall behind on payment. 
When cities cover the cost of monitoring, they often pay private contractors $2 to $3 a day for the same equipment and services for which the monitoring company charges defendants $10 a day. To come up with the money, the monitoring company's clients told ProPublica, they had to find second jobs, take their children out of day care and cut into disability checks. Others hurried to plead guilty for no better reason than that being on probation was cheaper than paying for a monitor. (üì∏: Zora J Murff for The New York Times)

The U.S. Customs and Border Protection agency has opened an investigation into vulgar and misogynistic social media posts made by members of a secret Facebook group for current and former Border Patrol agents.

On Monday, ‚ÄúU.S. Customs and Border Protection was made aware of disturbing social media activity hosted on a private Facebook group that may include a number of CBP employees,‚Äù said Matthew Klein, head of the agency‚Äôs internal affairs unit.

Klein said CBP ‚Äúimmediately informed‚Äù the investigators with the Department of Homeland Security‚Äôs Office of Inspector General and initiated an inquiry. The office typically takes the first look at allegations of serious misconduct within the CBP.

The investigation comes after a ProPublica report exposing the secret three-year-old Facebook group, which is called ‚ÄúI‚Äôm 10-15‚Äù and has some 9,500 members. Group members posted offensive graphics, including a photo illustration of Democratic Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez being sexually assaulted by President Donald Trump; discussed plans to disrupt a congressional visit to a Border Patrol facility; and joked about the deaths of migrants.

Recent posts shared with ProPublica include a meme using graphic language to mock CNN anchor Anderson Cooper‚Äôs sexual orientation and a comment that referred to soccer star Megan Rapinoe as a man. A separate thread made fun of a video of a migrant man trying to carry a child through a rushing river in a plastic bag.

One poster wrote, ‚ÄúAt least it‚Äôs already in a trash bag.‚Äù Another wrote, ‚ÄúSous-vide? Lol,‚Äù referring to a method of cooking in a bag.

üëáImpact from our reporting: U.S. Attorney General William P. Barr declared an emergency for public safety in rural Alaska on Friday and announced more than $10 million in funds as part of a sweeping plan to support law enforcement in Alaska Native villages.

The U.S. Department of Justice will immediately provide $6 million to the state to hire, equip and train rural police, and for mobile holding cells. An additional $4.5 million will support 20 officer positions and be provided to Alaska Native organizations by the end of July.

The announcement follows an investigation by the Anchorage Daily News and ProPublica, which found that one in three communities in Alaska, about 70 altogether and nearly all of them Alaska Native, had no local law enforcement at some point this year. Many are in regions with the highest rates of poverty, sexual assault and suicide in the United States.

In some hub communities that do have police, survivors of sexual assault say rapists go unpunished. Mothers of Alaska Native women who were found dead under suspicious circumstances say cases go unsolved.

Barr visited Alaska in May to hear concerns from Alaska Natives and rural residents about a lack of police in rural communities and high rates of sexual assault and family violence. During a trip to a Western Alaska village, Barr called the situation an ‚Äúemergency‚Äù and vowed to do everything he could to help. ‚ÄúIn May, when I visited Alaska, I witnessed firsthand the complex, unique, and dire law enforcement challenges the State of Alaska and its remote Alaska Native communities are facing,‚Äù Barr said in a statement Friday. ‚ÄúWith this emergency declaration, I am directing resources where they are needed most and needed immediately, to support the local law enforcement response in Alaska Native communities, whose people are dealing with extremely high rates of violence.‚Äù The state‚Äôs largest Native organization praised the decision. ‚ÄúWe appreciate that U.S. Attorney General William Barr clearly understands the urgency of the public safety situation in rural Alaska,‚Äù said Julie Kitka, longtime president of the Alaska Federation of Natives. (üì∏ Marc Lester, Anchorage Daily News)

A jumble of electrical cables dangles from a hole punched through the ceiling in Sheriff Blake Turman‚Äôs brightly lit office in rural Covington County, Alabama, near the Florida Panhandle.

A year ago, Turman‚Äôs predecessor, Dennis Meeks, used sheriff‚Äôs office funds to buy and install a security camera system, financial records show. But the equipment is no longer there. ‚ÄúYou see them wires hanging right there?‚Äù Turman asked during an interview in the office, which he took over in January, several months after beating Meeks in a runoff. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where the closed-circuit camera system used to be. He spent $2,800 putting that in there ‚Äî $2,800 out of discretionary funds, and it‚Äôs gone now.‚Äù Turman says he has thoroughly searched the sheriff‚Äôs office building for the equipment and has not been able to find it.

The missing video system is just one of a wide array of vagaries and shortfalls Turman says he has had to contend with since he replaced Meeks as sheriff on Jan. 14. Records were destroyed or removed, he said, while public accounts were depleted to buy a computer system that the office can‚Äôt use and ammunition for guns that sheriff‚Äôs deputies don‚Äôt carry. Turman also said tens of thousands of public dollars were missing from those same accounts and provided a reporter with internal sheriff‚Äôs office records that he says support his claims.

Nine sheriffs who took office this year across the state have alleged that their predecessors destroyed public property, wasted taxpayer money or took other steps that abused the public trust and undermined their offices, as AL.com and ProPublica first reported this month. A handful have asked the state to audit their offices. (üì∏: Art Meripol)

After years of working as a sheriff‚Äôs deputy and a car dealership manager, John Ingrum used his savings to buy a farm some 50 miles east of Jackson, Mississippi. He planned to raise horses on the land and leave the property to his son.

The farm, named Lovin‚Äô Acres, came with a few chicken houses, which didn‚Äôt really interest Ingrum. But then a man showed up from Koch Foods, the country‚Äôs fifth-largest poultry processor and one of the main chicken companies in Mississippi. Koch Foods would deliver flocks and feed ‚Äî all Ingrum would have to do is house the chicks for a few weeks while they grew big enough to slaughter. The company representative wowed Ingrum with projections for the stream of income he could earn, Ingrum recalled in an interview.
What Ingrum didn‚Äôt know was that those financial projections overlooked many realities of modern farming in the U.S., where much of the country‚Äôs agricultural output is controlled by a handful of giant companies. The numbers didn‚Äôt reflect the debt he might have to incur to configure his chicken houses to the company‚Äôs specifications. Nor did they reflect the risk that the chicks could show up sick or dead, or that the company could simply stop delivering flocks. 
The shadow of slavery, sharecropping and Jim Crow has left black farmers in an especially precarious position. While white farmers benefited from government assistance such as the Homestead Act and land-grant universities, black farmers were largely excluded from owning land and accumulating wealth. In recent decades, black farmers accused the USDA of discriminating against them by denying them loans or forcing them to wait longer, resulting in a class-action lawsuit that settled for more than $1 billion. Along with these historical disadvantages, black farmers say they have also encountered bias in dealing with some of the corporate giants that control their livelihood. In complaints filed with the USDA between 2010 and 2015, Ingrum and another black farmer in Mississippi said Koch Foods discriminated against them and used its market control to drive them out of business.
(üì∏: Carlton Sanders, pictured, was the last black farmer under contract with Koch in MS.)

When his son was born Jorge Matias held the infant in the hospital and sang him the lullabies he had learned as a child in Guatemala. He teased the boy‚Äôs mother that he would raise their son to speak Spanish, and one day the two of them would talk in secret around her.

But the boy was born with heroin in his system and, when it cleared from his body, Illinois child welfare officials placed him in a foster home. To get his son back, Matias had to complete a long list of requirements, including ending his relationship with the boy‚Äôs mother, a heroin addict. 
Matias visited the boy at his caseworker‚Äôs office, changed diapers and learned to prepare a bottle. He documented his son‚Äôs growth with photos and videos on his cellphone.

Shortly before the boy turned 1, at a visit with his father at a library, his foster mother sitting nearby, he spoke what was, for Matias, his child‚Äôs first word. Not in Spanish. Or in English. But in Slovak. Mamka. Mommy..

Documents obtained by ProPublica show that the Walton Family Foundation, a staunch supporter of school choice and Teach For America‚Äôs largest private funder, was paying $4,000 for every teacher placed in a traditional public school ‚Äî and $6,000 for every one placed in a charter school. The two-year grant was directed at nine cities where charter schools were sprouting up, including New Orleans; Memphis, Tennessee; and Los Angeles.

The gift‚Äôs purpose was far removed from Teach For America‚Äôs original mission of alleviating teacher shortages in traditional public schools. It was intended to ‚Äúgenerate a longer-term leadership pipeline that advances the education movement, providing a source of talent for policy, advocacy and politics, as well as quality schools and new entrepreneurial ventures,‚Äù according to internal grant documents.

The incentives corresponded to a shift in Teach For America‚Äôs direction. Although only 7% of students go to charter schools, Teach For America sent almost 40% of its 6,736 teachers to them in 2018 ‚Äî up from 34% in 2015 and 13% in 2008. In some large cities, charter schools employ the majority of TFA teachers: 54% in Houston, 58% in San Antonio and at least 70% in Los Angeles.

Read more at ProPublica.org.

Since 2011, when the U.S. Supreme Court ordered California to overhaul its overcrowded prisons, inmate-on-inmate homicides have risen 46% in county jails statewide compared with the seven years before, a McClatchy and ProPublica analysis of California Department of Justice data and autopsy records shows.

Killings tripled and even quadrupled in several counties.

Inmates have stabbed, bludgeoned or strangled their cellmates, moved bodies and wiped away blood before guards noticed, autopsy reports show. Staff at the jails have missed several of the crimes entirely, only finding the bodies hours later.

The state holds more than 70,000 inmates spread across 56 counties with jails. Many inmates now are serving multiyear sentences in jails originally designed to hold people no longer than a year. An increasing number of jail inmates suffer from serious mental illness or chronic medical conditions that those facilities have been unprepared to handle.

The surge in killings in county jails is particularly significant because the population there is vastly different than in prisons. The majority of people in jails statewide are accused of crimes, innocent under the law, whereas prisons only hold those who have been convicted of felonies.

Did you know that chicken farming is... well... kind of like driving for Uber? ü§®üêî Stay with us here. A few large companies dominate the market, and they pretty much call the shots for the farmers ‚Äî from birds to feed to pricing. 
Chicken companies contract with local farmers to raise and care for birds for several weeks until they‚Äôre ready for slaughter. The farmers bear the cost of housing the birds, equipment and fuel. The companies, in addition to delivering chicks and feed, rank the farmers based on how plump their birds get and pay accordingly. This so-called ‚Äútournament system‚Äù rewards the most efficient producers, the companies argue, but farmers say the companies control key variables, such as who receives the healthiest chicks and the most nutritious feed, and, thus, who comes out on top.

One clear indicator of companies‚Äô growing leverage over farmers: Farmers‚Äô average pay rose by just 2.5 cents a pound from 1988 to 2016, while the wholesale price of chicken increased by 17.4 cents a pound, data from the USDA and the National Chicken Council shows. 
The main law regulating meatpackers was passed almost a century ago after a Federal Trade Commission investigation found that five companies had a stranglehold over the country‚Äôs meat supply and used it to fix prices, crush competition and defraud farmers and consumers.

The Packers and Stockyards Act of 1921 prohibited meatpackers from engaging in unfair and deceptive practices, manipulating prices, creating monopolies or giving undue preference to particular people, businesses or places. The law‚Äôs scope expanded over the next several decades to apply to livestock dealers, live poultry dealers, swine contractors and other related businesses.

Eventually, however, courts, the Justice Department, the FTC and the USDA softened their stance on consolidation. From 1986 to 2016, the top four companies‚Äô market share rose from 55% to 84% in beef processing, 33% to 66% in pork, and 34% to 50% in chicken, according to USDA data. Counting the fifth-largest chicken company, the top firms control 61% of the market.

But paying $1 million directly to the president‚Äôs business? That‚Äôs perfectly legal.

The inauguration of Donald Trump was a watershed for the payday lending industry. It had been feeling beleaguered since the launch of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in 2011. For the first time, the industry had come under federal supervision. Payday lending companies were suddenly subject to exams conducted by the bureau‚Äôs supervision division, which could, and sometimes did, lead to enforcement cases.

Before the bureau was created, payday lenders had been overseen mostly by state authorities. That left a patchwork: 15 states in which payday loans were banned outright, a handful of states with strong enforcement ‚Äî and large swaths of the country in which payday lending was mostly unregulated.

Then, almost as suddenly as an aggressive CFPB emerged, the Trump administration arrived with an agenda of undoing regulations. ‚ÄúThere was a resurgence of hope in the industry, which seems to be justified, at this point,‚Äù said Jeremy Rosenblum, a partner at law firm Ballard Spahr, who represents payday lenders. Rosenblum spoke to ProPublica and WNYC in a conference room at the Doral ‚Äî filled with notepads, pens and little bowls of candy marked with the Trump name and family crest ‚Äî where he had just led a session on compliance with federal and state laws. ‚ÄúThere was a profound sense of relief, or hope, for the first time.‚Äù Listen to the podcast at the link in our bio üéß

Seven years ago this month, Beth Crowder and David Wentz told natural gas giant EQT Corp. that it did not have permission to come onto their West Virginia farm to drill for the natural gas beneath neighboring properties.

The company ignored their warnings. It built roads and drilled a well, and it put in horizontal pipes stretching for miles in all directions.

Crowder and Wentz sued ‚Äî and they‚Äôve been fighting EQT in court ever since. On Wednesday, the West Virginia Supreme Court ended the matter with a surprisingly straightforward and unanimous conclusion: Going onto someone else‚Äôs land without their permission is trespassing. (üì∏ Raymond Thompson Jr., special to ProPublica)

Congressional leaders are planning to scrap a provision of an IRS reform bill making permanent the Free File deal between the government and private tax filing companies, torpedoing a long-sought goal by industry giant Intuit, the maker of TurboTax.

The development, first reported by Politico Pro and confirmed to ProPublica by a House Republican staffer, comes two months after an outcry sparked by our story on the Free File provision in a bill called the Taxpayer First Act.

The bill, which has bipartisan support and contains a range of provisions including restrictions on the private debt collection of unpaid taxes, passed the House in April but stalled in the Senate.

Under the Free File program, the industry promises to offer a no-fee option to most Americans and in return the IRS pledges not to develop its own free, online filing service. Such an IRS program would threaten the industry‚Äôs profits. Only a small percentage of eligible Americans use the Free File options, and many are instead steered to paid products by the industry.

The new bill, without the Free File provision, could be introduced today and voted on in the House as soon as next week, according to Politico. The bill‚Äôs Republican sponsor in the Senate, Sen. Chuck Grassley, told Bloomberg, ‚ÄúIn order to get it through the Senate, we have to‚Äù drop the Free File provision. Rep. John Lewis, the bill‚Äôs Democratic sponsor in the House, told Tax Notes that the updated legislation is expected soon.

A spokesman for Intuit, which spent $2.6 million last year lobbying on Free File and other issues, declined to comment on the Taxpayer First Act.

Nine months and a long Arctic winter have come and gone since the abduction, sexual assault and murder of 10-year-old Ashley Johnson-Barr in the northwest Alaska hub community of Kotzebue.

Signs of Ashley can be found everywhere in this town of 3,200. At the cemetery, groups of kids gather at the purple-painted wooden cross marking her grave. They leave trinkets, teddy bears, necklaces, even sports medals. People slip bouquets of artificial flowers through the chain link fence at Rainbow Park, where the fifth grader was last seen playing on a Thursday evening in September.

Her death lingers in other ways. The crime stunned Kotzebue and the rest of Alaska, galvanizing calls for everything from more robust public safety protections to action against the state‚Äôs high rate of child sexual abuse.

Mandy Hill, who has worked with kids in Kotzebue for 16 years, said some parents who‚Äôd allowed their children to roam the town are hesitant now. ‚ÄúYou hold your kids closer. You watch more. You kind of hold back on letting them play out,‚Äù she said.

Ashley‚Äôs death also spurred a new level of public conversation about sexual abuse, one of Alaska‚Äôs most wrenching problems. ‚ÄúOur daughter started something,‚Äù Scotty Barr, Ashley‚Äôs father, said. ‚ÄúNo more silence.‚Äù Read more about why and how we are investigating sexual violence in Alaska at the link in our bio. (üì∏: Bill Roth/Anchorage Daily News)

We're investigating the state of California's broken prison system. We know not everyone is familiar with the subject, so we put together some background info to help you get up to speed. 
A decade ago, so many inmates were crammed into California‚Äôs prisons that the sprawling system had reached a breaking point. Prisoners were sleeping in gyms, hallways and dayrooms. Mentally ill prisoners were jammed into tiny holding cells. There were dozens of riots and hundreds of attacks on guards every year. Suicide rates were 80% higher than in the rest of the nation‚Äôs prisons.

The California prison population peaked at more than 165,000 in 2006 ‚Äî in a system designed to house just 85,000. That dubious mountaintop came after years of tougher and tougher laws like mandatory sentences, juveniles prosecuted as adults and a ‚ÄúThree Strikes‚Äù initiative overwhelmingly approved by voters in 1994.

Since then, California has struggled to deal with a cascading series of problems and almost constant oversight by federal judges. In recent years, the state has undergone the biggest transformation to its prisons since the first, San Quentin, opened in 1851.

Read more about this at the link in our bio and follow the investigation by signing up for the newsletter. All of us at ProPublica and the Sacramento Bee sincerely appreciate it. üëâhttps://go.propublica.org/overcorrection

From 2009 to 2014, at least 214 complaints were filed against federal agents for abusing or mistreating migrant children. According to the Department of Homeland Security‚Äôs records, only one employee was disciplined as a result of a complaint.

We‚Äôve heard from transgender and nonbinary travelers that the TSA screening process sometimes results in them being questioned or experiencing invasive screenings simply because their bodies looked different than an officer expected.

If you‚Äôve had a problem at TSA related to your gender identity, we want to talk to you.

We‚Äôre especially interested in hearing about situations like these: - A TSA officer asked you to show sensitive parts of your body.
- A TSA officer asked you to ‚Äúprove‚Äù your sex or gender.
- A TSA officer made derogatory comments about your gender identity or made inappropriate remarks about your body.

Here's how to get in touch:
- Share information with us using this form on our website: http://bit.ly/propublica-tsa
- Send us a DM and we‚Äôll get you in touch with our reporters

Every year, the IRS, starved of funds after years of budget cuts, loses hundreds more agents to retirement. And every year, the news gets better for the rich ‚Äî especially those prone to go bold on their taxes. According to data released by the IRS last week, millionaires in 2018 were about 80% less likely to be audited than they were in 2011.

But poor taxpayers continue to bear the brunt of the IRS‚Äô remaining force. As we reported last year, Americans who receive the earned income tax credit, one of the country‚Äôs largest anti-poverty programs, are audited at a higher rate than all but the richest taxpayers. The new data shows that the trend has only grown stronger.

Audits of the rich continue to plunge while those of the poor hold steady, and the two audit rates are converging. Last year, the top 1% of taxpayers by income were audited at a rate of 1.56%. EITC recipients, who typically have annual income under $20,000, were audited at 1.41%. Part of the reason is ease. Audits of EITC recipients are largely automated and far less complicated. ‚ÄúWhile the wealthy now have an open invitation to cheat, low-income taxpayers are receiving heightened scrutiny because they can be audited far more easily. All it takes is a letter instead of a team of investigators and lawyers,‚Äù said Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., the ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee. ‚ÄúWe have two tax systems in this country,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúand nothing illustrates that better than the IRS ignoring wealthy tax cheats while penalizing low-income workers over small mistakes.‚Äù In a statement, IRS spokesman Dean Patterson acknowledged that the sharp decline in audits of the wealthy is due to the agency having lost so many skilled auditors. And he didn‚Äôt dispute that pursuing the poor is just easier.

Because EITC audits are largely conducted through the mail by lower-level employees from a central location, they are ‚Äúless burdensome for taxpayers than in-person audits as they mail in their documentation and don‚Äôt have to take time out of the workday,‚Äù Patterson said. ‚ÄúCorrespondence audits are also the most efficient use of IRS‚Äô limited examination resources.‚Äù

Life in Kotzebue came to a standstill last fall when a 10-year-old girl vanished from a playground in the center of this northwest arctic town. After searchers found her body hidden in the tundra, police charged a local man with kidnapping, sexual abuse and murder.

As one of the reporters covering the case, I tried to learn as much as possible about the 42-year-old suspect. He was a lifelong Alaskan and was not a registered sex offender. Yet two family members soon told me he had raped them decades earlier when they were girls, beginning a pattern of abuse. (He has pleaded not guilty to charges stemming from the Kotzebue homicide and has not responded to his relatives‚Äô claims.) Around the same time, a police dispatcher in Nome said her colleagues ignored her when she attempted to report that she had been raped on camera, prompting demotions and upheaval within that seaside police department. Inspired by the dispatcher‚Äôs willingness to share her tale, a young woman from the nearby village of St. Michael said she too had been raped in Nome and that no one faced charges. As one article led to the next, more and more survivors of sexual assault in Alaska agreed to tell their stories.

Here is what hit me the hardest about the interviews: Each person had more than one story to tell. I might ask someone about a specific sexual assault that occurred in the past few years, only to learn she also had been victimized as a child, and again as a teen and as an adult. Sometimes the crimes were reported to police, sometimes not. Sometimes the victims were adults, sometimes children. Mostly women, but sometimes men.

I can‚Äôt recall one instance, from those interviews in the fall, in which a survivor said someone was ever held accountable. 
Read more at the link in our bio Partner: @anchoragedailynews

Under a deal with the government, service members making under $66,000 are **supposed** to be able to file with TurboTax for free.

We tested "TurboTax Military" and TurboTax Free File using the tax information of a Virginia-based Navy sailor and his graphic designer wife with a household income of $53,000. "TurboTax Military" tried to upgrade us or convince us to pay for side products six times. We declined those extras each time. Finally, the program told us we had to pay $159.98 to finish filing.

And that ‚Äúmilitary discount‚Äù? All of $5.

In the (non-advertised) Free File version, by contrast, we were able to file completely free.

Here‚Äôs what happened when we landed on TurboTax Military:

The software took us through filing our taxes in the standard question-answer format used across all TurboTax products. We entered the sailor‚Äôs employer and income information.

Then TurboTax told us we were going to save some money because of our service. ‚ÄúCongrats! You qualify for our Enlisted military discount.‚Äù We were then repeatedly offered other paid products.

TurboTax recommended we purchase ‚Äú+PLUS,‚Äù which promises ‚Äú24/7 tax return access‚Äù and other services for $19.99.

We were offered ‚ÄúTurboTaxLive‚Äù ‚Äî access to advice from a CPA ‚Äî for $194.99.

We were also offered ‚ÄúMAX,‚Äù which includes audit defense and identity loss insurance for $59.99 (a good deal, the company suggests, because the products represent a ‚Äú$125.00 value‚Äù). We rejected all of these offers. We finished filing the sailor‚Äôs military income and added his wife‚Äôs 1099 income of $15,000 and her modest business expenses.

When we were done entering their information, the software broke some bad news: We would need to upgrade to TurboTax Self-Employed for $114.99 (minus $5 thanks to the military discount). On top of that, we were charged $44.99 to file Virginia state taxes, bringing our total to $159.98.

When we started on TurboTax Free File instead of TurboTax Military and entered the same information, the filing experience was virtually identical, with two major differences: We weren‚Äôt pitched side products such as audit defense and the final price was $0.

In southwest Connecticut, the gap between rich and poor is wider than anywhere else in the country. Invisible walls created by local zoning boards and the state government block affordable housing and, by extension, the people who need it.

An investigation by the Connecticut Mirror and ProPublica has found that more than three dozen Connecticut towns have blocked construction of any privately developed duplexes and apartments within their borders for the last two decades, often through exclusionary zoning requirements. In 18 of those towns, it‚Äôs been at least 28 years.

In Westport ‚Äî where gated residences overlook the Long Island Sound and voters solidly backed Democrats in the most recent state and presidential elections ‚Äî private developers have been allowed to open just 65 affordable housing units over the last three decades. Public housing rentals operated by the local housing authority have also grown at a snail‚Äôs pace, with 71 new units opening in this charming small town of 10,400 homes.

The impact of this logjam on families is that the share of housing specifically dedicated for low-income residents has actually decreased by small percentages in one-quarter of Connecticut‚Äôs municipalities since 1990. 
Ashana Cunningham, a 33-year-old mother of three, lives 9 miles from Westport‚Äôs posh downtown. 
Each workday, she takes a bus from a homeless shelter in Bridgeport, where she lives with her family among a landscape of abandoned factories, run-down houses and trash-lined streets to her job in a suburban cornucopia a few miles away. (üì∏: Cloe Poisson, special to ProPublica)

This is Annie Reed. She‚Äôs a cop, outnumbered by registered sex offenders 7-to-1. She doesn‚Äôt wear a uniform, but everybody in Kiana, the tiny Alaskan town north of the Arctic Circle she serves, recognizes her from a distance. In an emergency, nobody calls 911. They contact Reed directly.

In spring, 2018, Reed‚Äôs radio crackled to life. A local sex offender, Edmond Morris, pried open a window, tore the clothes from a village elder‚Äôs daughter, gripped her throat, and raped her, according to charges against him in state court, which he denies.

In remote western Alaska, sex crime rates are double the statewide average. That statewide average is nearly triple the U.S. average. Why? A two-tiered justice system leaves mostly native and remote Alaskan villages unprotected.

Our investigation took a look at towns with some of the highest rates of rape and child sexual abuse in the U.S. Our investigation took us to some of the most remote parts of Alaska. Our investigation won‚Äôt stop here. 
Read the full investigation on our website. (üì∑: @holmesphoto)

For @ProPublica, photographer @ashgilbertson of @viiphoto wrote about his experience photographing the industrial palm oil production encroaching on Indonesia‚Äôs forests. Read an excerpt from his essay and click the link in our bio to read the full story.

BEA NEHAS, BORNEO ‚Äî Yunta Herlambang, a chief of the Wehea tribe in Indonesia‚Äôs East Kalimantan province, is preparing to lead a warrior initiation ceremony, known as a Nemlen, the first of its type in 16 years. He slips out of cargo shorts and a blue T-shirt and puts on chest plates adorned with monkey heads and long-bill beaks. Around his waist, he ties a mandau, the traditional and widely feared sword carried by Dayaks. The uninitiated are not permitted to touch a mandau that has taken an enemy head, and Yunta‚Äôs is off limits, he tells me.

We‚Äôre in Bea Nehas, a tiny village surrounded by miles and miles of palm plantations. The small plots that homes are built on are in constant jeopardy of being burned to the ground and bulldozed, just as the residents‚Äô old village, farther upstream, was razed by land developers 40 years ago. ‚ÄúIn the name of prosperity,‚Äù Yunta exclaims. An intensity comes to his reddened eyes, and he drops his voice. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what the government always tells us.‚Äù The sprawling roughly 100,000-acre plantation that surrounds the village is run by DSN, one of Indonesia‚Äôs largest producers of palm oil. Here alone, they employ at least 8,000 mostly migrant workers, and say they have brought in experts to help them better understand the local culture and the concerns of surrounding communities. ‚ÄúIn the past, these people were just hunting and doing some things in the forest,‚Äù said Kokok Butianto, 50, the head of DSN‚Äôs corporate social responsibility team. ‚ÄúBut we want to do things to empower the communities, their education, their culture.‚Äù #borneo #indonesia #palmoil #agriculture #globalwarming #climatechange #journalism #photojournalist #orangutan

Alauddin Akonjee was a Muslim immigrant from Bangladesh, the imam at a Queens mosque, and devoted to his religious obligations. Minara, his wife of nearly 30 years, was devoted to making sure the imam met those obligations. She would lay his clothes out on the bed, and, after he‚Äôd gone off to the mosque, she‚Äôd make sure a lunch was ready for him, typically a meal of rice and curried fish.

On Aug. 13, 2016, Alauddin did not show up for his rice and fish. Instead, it was the wife of one of the imam‚Äôs best friends who turned up. The world Minara had made for herself and her family was over. A gunman had shot Alauddin dead in the streets of Queens. His friend, Thara Miah, had been slain as well. The gunman had fled, and his reason for killing the two men, the authorities said at the time, was a mystery: There had been no dispute; the men‚Äôs valuables had not been stolen. Alauddin is survived by his wife and seven kids.

For Minara, there was no question about the gunman‚Äôs motive: Alauddin had been targeted because of his faith.

In Dec. 2016, Detective Jessica LaBorde interrogated 12-year-old Bobby Lewis alone in the police station in Ville Platte, LA. Sheepish about repeating the words, Bobby said LaBorde called him a ‚ÄúB‚Äù and an ‚ÄúMF‚Äù while accusing him of throwing a rock through a window and a host of other crimes.
.
[photos by @edmundfountain]
.

Bobby said LaBorde threatened to confiscate his dog, Cinnamon, and throw his mom in jail if he didn‚Äôt own up to the crimes. But Bobby said he wasn‚Äôt involved in any of the crimes she accused him of.
.

What LaBorde did to Bobby is likely unconstitutional. The police can‚Äôt take somebody into custody without probable cause. (LaBorde never responded to our requests for comment.)
.

Two weeks after Bobby was detained, the Justice Department issued a scathing report on policing in Ville Platte and surrounding Evangeline Parish. The DOJ was preparing a reform plan, called a ‚Äúconsent decree,‚Äù to stop police abuse.
.

But then Donald Trump was elected and Jeff Sessions became attorney general.

In 2011 Oscar Ram√≠rez Casta√±eda, a married father of four living near Boston, learned that his life was a lie. He was not the son of a heroic Guatemalan military officer, as he‚Äôd been told by the family that raised him. DNA tests proved that he‚Äôd been kidnapped at age three by the officer, whose commando unit had massacred Oscar‚Äôs entire village ‚Äì one of the worst crimes in Guatemala‚Äôs bloody civil war.

ProPublica chronicled the story of Oscar, who was living as an undocumented immigrant, in the 2012 series ‚ÄúFinding Oscar.‚Äù Four months after its publication, the story put enough political pressure on U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services to grant political asylum to Oscar and his wife. The couple has since received permanent residency, work authorization and Social Security cards. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have to look over my shoulder anymore when I‚Äôm driving,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúEven though I am a very good driver, that worry could be really hard.‚Äù .
Attention from the story also enabled his real father, Tranquilino Casta√±eda, to receive a visa and travel to the U.S. to meet Oscar. Tranquilino, who had been away from the village during the massacre, thought his son had been killed.
.
The story additionally spurred efforts. to bring to justice fugitive commandos involved in such violence during the civil war. Since the story authorities have caught or convicted 10 former soldiers.

Newly grieving the murder of her son Kevin in 2015, Marcia DeOliveira-Longinetti had to attend to his affairs ‚Äî including the matter of his student loans. When she called a New Jersey state agency that had lent Kevin money, she got a curt letter saying there would be no reprieve. They would continue to send monthly bills of $180 to Marcia, who had co-signed the loan, until it was repaid in full.
.
ProPublica interviewed Marcia for an investigation on the NJ agency, called the Higher Education Student Assistance Authority. The agency pushes incredibly burdensome student loans, backed by Wall Street, with stringent rules, aggressive collections and few breaks, even for borrowers who had died.
.
After the story, Gov. Chris Christie signed into law a new requirement for the state‚Äôs student loan agency to forgive the debts of borrowers who die or become permanently disabled. And DeOliveira-Longinetti has stopped receiving monthly bills for the loan.
.
‚ÄúAll I wanted to do was fix a problem that nobody was paying attention to,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSenators were oblivious that this was happening. Parents weren‚Äôt talking to each other about the problems they were having with student loans. If ProPublica hadn‚Äôt covered this, nobody would have known it was happening. To be a part of it was awesome.‚Äù
.

In 2008, a jury found Demetrius Smith guilty of murder, a crime he maintained he didn‚Äôt commit. He served more than 5 years before he was proven innocent. Because of this injustice, when Smith was wrongfully convicted of another shooting, he reluctantly took a special plea deal that allowed him to maintain his innocence and be released, while the felony conviction was left on his record. .
ProPublica documented the consequences of this bad deal, called an Alford plea, telling the story of Demetrius and other defendants. While he avoided prison time, Demetrius found that the felony conviction had other consequences: ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt get housing, you can‚Äôt get certain jobs,‚Äù he said. He made a request to revise his Alford plea and clear his record, but the prosecutor vetoed the request.
.
Weeks after ProPublica‚Äôs story, the prosecutor admitted he‚Äôd been wrong and asked a judge to schedule a new hearing. In January 2018, that hearing ended with Demetrius‚Äô felony conviction cleared from his record. ‚ÄúThe story made people see what actually goes on in a courtroom with these prosecutors,‚Äù Demetrius said. ‚ÄúThis type of stuff happens all the time and doesn‚Äôt get put out there enough.‚Äù
.
Today, Demetrius is working with partners to launch a business that will train people with felony convictions in landscaping and construction. Its name: Growing Opportunities. ‚ÄúI want to give everybody a shot, no matter what‚Äôs on their record, whether they were innocent or guilty, because everybody deserves a second chance,‚Äù said Smith. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think God brought me this far for nothing. There‚Äôs a reason.‚Äù
.

In 2011, the Zetas drug cartel swept through the small Mexican town of Allende, kidnapping and killing dozens, possibly hundreds, of men, women and children. Lost in the slaughter was Mar√≠a Eugenia Vela‚Äôs husband, Edgar, an engineer. The night he disappeared, their daughter was just six years old, and Vela was pregnant with their second child, a son.
.
‚ÄúThe authorities were totally apathetic,‚Äù Vela said of the lack of any investigation into the massacre, even after she filed a report about Edgar‚Äôs disappearance. Some in the community suggested that the victims may have been involved with drug trafficking. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt understand how this disappearance of my husband came to pass.‚Äù

It was a shock when ProPublica reporter Ginger Thompson showed up on her doorstep in 2016, requesting to interview her for an oral history about what happened in Allende. The story, co-published with National Geographic, revealed a scandal: a botched U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration investigation had triggered the Allende ¬†massacre.
.
The story vindicated Mar√≠a‚Äôs husband, finally giving her answers. ‚ÄúI can explain to my children how it happened,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt gives me relief that there is, written in full, a journalistic testimony of what happened to their father.‚Äù
.
The story also got the attention of senior lawmakers in Washington. Democratic leaders in the House and Senate, citing ProPublica‚Äôs reporting, called for an investigation into the DEA‚Äôs role in triggering violent drug cartel attacks.

Noemi Martinez of Jacksonville, Fla., was in a desperate hurry last July, as she ran to catch the bus to a job interview. Along the way, she veered off the sidewalk to avoid a showering sprinkler. She was stopped by a police officer who issued a $62.50 citation for ‚Äúwalking in roadway where sidewalks provided.‚Äù
.
ProPublica met Noemi while reporting with the Florida Times-Union on ¬†the phenomenon of ‚ÄúWalking While Black,‚Äù looking at racial disparities in who gets stopped and penalized for Jacksonville‚Äôs pedestrian violations. The story revealed that African Americans receive 55 percent of all pedestrian tickets in Jacksonville, while only accounting for 29 percent of the population.
.
After the story was published, a defense attorney reached out to Noemi and offered to represent her pro bono in contesting the ticket. She was still ruled in violation of the statute, but the judge reduced her fine from $62.50 to $25. Noemi saw no justice in the reduction. ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt have had to pay a penny because I didn‚Äôt do anything wrong,‚Äù she said.
.
But the reporting made a difference for Noemi another way. ‚ÄúThere are so many people defending the police department, and, until ProPublica, my voice was not being heard,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI thank ProPublica for shining light on a dark place for me. The story gave me hope.‚Äù

Four days after Marie McCausland gave birth, the hospital sent her and her husband home with their baby boy. Hours later, she felt awful: severe chest pain, a splitting headache. .
Marie remembered the ProPublica/NPR story she‚Äôd read one week earlier about Lauren Bloomstein, ¬†who died soon after childbirth from preeclampsia, a type of high blood pressure. Recognizing her symptoms in herself, Marie rushed to the closest emergency room in Cleveland.
.
The first ER doctor she saw tried sending her back home with meds, but Marie stood her ground. She waited ¬†seven hours before the doctor consulted with an OB-GYN ‚Äî who immediately registered her symptoms as preeclampsia.
.
‚ÄúProPublica‚Äôs reporting literally saved my life, and it‚Äôs changed the course of my life,‚Äù said Marie, who had spent the better part of her graduate career working to become an HIV researcher. ‚ÄúNow I‚Äôm trying to figure out how to get into maternal health advocacy as a career.‚Äù
.
She‚Äôs off to a good start. A few months after her experience, Marie contacted the hospital, which updated its discharge papers to include potentially dangerous postpartum systems. Now new mothers know what conditions to look out for.

Eight years ago, Bil Musgrave was diagnosed with a rare cancer. He retired from his job as a coal miner in Warrick County, Ind., and focused on treatment, which was covered by the lifetime health insurance provided to him by the Squaw Creek Coal Company. Miraculously, he survived. The insurance also covered Bil‚Äôs numerous medications.
.
He was floored when ProPublica called in 2015 with the news that Patriot Coal (which managed operations for his former employer) had gone bankrupt, and his health care was going to be cut off. 
As ProPublica reported, millions of dollars for the health insurance of retired coal miners would be diverted to Patriot Coal‚Äôs legal fees. ‚ÄúIt was just devastating,‚Äù said Bil. ‚ÄúAnd it was all hidden in the bankruptcy filings.‚Äù
.
A week after ProPublica‚Äôs story shined a light on the plan, Patriot Coal announced that it would no longer strip retirees‚Äô insurance benefits. Musgrave, along with hundreds of other families who were at risk, will continue to receive lifetime health care. ‚ÄúNo news organizations knew about it until after ProPublica reported it‚Äù said Bil, who attributes the retention of his insurance to our reporting.

In 2012, Isaura Martinez was working as a temp in Chicago. Like the city‚Äôs many other immigrant workers employed by temp agencies, she boarded vans each day to work in hazardous conditions at a rotating series of factories and warehouses, often without safety training and protective equipment. Those rides, arranged by the agencies, came with high fees, as did cashing her paychecks. At the end of the day, she earned less than minimum wage. .
Though initially apprehensive to talk to ProPublica, doing so gave Isaura confidence to speak out. ‚ÄúI felt sincerely happy to get it off my chest ‚Äî I freed myself,‚Äù she said of sharing her story. ‚ÄúIt motivated me to continue denouncing these sorts of injustices.‚Äù Today Isaura is an organizer with the Chicago Workers Collaborative, where she advocates for temp workers. In 2016, she testified at a state hearing, aiding the passage of a bill that increased protections.
.
‚ÄúProPublica helped me to break my silence and fear,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMichael took the time to listen to me, and he was the first to do so. In the name of all the temp workers, thank you.‚Äù

Joe Bryan has spent the past three decades in prison for the murder of his wife, a crime he claims he didn‚Äôt commit.
.
Prosecutors asked the jury to believe that between 9:15 p.m. on Oct. 14, 1985, when the Bryans spoke by phone, and the following morning, when Mickey was found shot to death, Joe slipped out of his hotel in Austin; drove 120 miles to Clifton, at night, through heavy rain, even though he had an eye condition that made night driving difficult; shot his wife, with whom he had no history of conflict; drove 120 miles back to Austin; re-entered the hotel; and stole upstairs to his room ‚Äî all in time to clean up and attend the conference‚Äôs morning session, and all without leaving behind a single eyewitness.
.
His conviction rested largely on ‚Äúbloodstain-pattern analysis‚Äù ‚Äî a technique still in use throughout the criminal-justice system, despite concerns about its reliability.
.
Read Parts I and II of Blood Will Tell, our investigation with @nytmag on ProPublica.org.
.

Every year in the United States, between 700 and 900 women die from causes related to pregnancy and childbirth.
.

The U.S. rate of maternal mortality is substantially higher than those of other affluent nations and has risen over the past decade. Black mothers suffer the most, dying at a rate more than triple that of white mothers.
.

Two coal-fired power plants in Adams County, OH are shutting down next month. The plants, both owned by Dayton Power & Light Co., are the biggest employer and taxpayer in the county.  The closure will result in an annual loss of $787,800 from the county general fund, about 9.8 percent of the annual budget. The Manchester Local School District in Adams County is expected to lose more than a third of its $11 million budget. Some of the more than 700 plants workers will move to find new jobs. But what will happen to the community in Adams County? Read the story on ProPublica.org.
.

Photography by Philip Montgomery for Bloomberg Businessweek.

Baylor St. Luke‚Äôs Medical Center in Houston has long claimed to be one of the best hospitals in the world for heart surgery.
.

St. Luke‚Äôs heart transplant survival rate, the most important measure of a program‚Äôs quality, now ranks near the bottom nationally, according to the most recently published data.
.
Among St. Luke‚Äôs patients who received a new heart between the summer of 2014 and the end of 2016, just 85 percent survived at least one year, compared to 91.4 percent nationally.
.

Dr. Jeffrey Morgan, the surgical director at St. Luke‚Äôs, said the hospital has rebounded. ‚ÄúWe only have had one year with below-expected outcomes in the recent past, 2015, and that's been corrected,‚Äù Morgan said.
.

Read the joint investigation by ProPublica and the Houston Chronicle at ProPublica.org.

New York City‚Äôs private garbage collection industry is rife with labor abuses and safety hazards.
.
Workers drive across the city every night collecting waste on routes that often snake through multiple boroughs.
.
Each NYC business chooses a company to collect its garbage. So, for example, in one five-block stretch near Rockefeller Center, 27 garbage companies stop at 86 businesses. The current system causes truck traffic, increased greenhouse gases and long routes for overworked drivers.
.
Mayor Bill de Blasio‚Äôs office proposed reforming the industry by introducing zoning, which would divide the city up into zones and allow only one company to bid and then operate in each area. The change could raise recycling rates and reduce traffic and emissions significantly ‚Äî and increase driver safety by shortening routes.
.

ProPublica Quiz: Bankruptcy Edition
.
The bankruptcy system is supposed to help people who are overwhelmed by debt get back on their feet. But is the system actually helping people?
.

Our investigation found that black people struggling with debt are pushed into a certain kind of bankruptcy -- Chapter 13 -- more often than white debtors. Chapter 13 is particularly common in the South. But those Chapter 13 cases often fail to relieve debt.
.
Take our quiz and see what surprises you about our bankruptcy system.
.
If you‚Äôve ever considered filing for bankruptcy, we want to hear your story. Just text ‚Äúhello‚Äù to 317-707-6371 and help us better understand how people make decisions about bankruptcy.

It‚Äôs ProPublica quiz time: Environmental justice edition. So what‚Äôs that mean? Here we go: Landfills, power plants and toxic waste facilities are disproportionately built in poor and minority communities. The disparity led to protests in the 1980s, and fuels a movement that continues to this day.
.
.
Despite some progress, these communities are still more likely to suffer significant health hazards and be exposed to poisoned air and water. Things may get worse as the Trump administration makes significant cuts to the Environmental Protection Agency -- which is charged with protecting these communities. What do you know about environmental justice? Take our quiz and tell us how you did in the comments. We‚Äôll praise you if you do well (that‚Äôs all we can really offer). Check in with ProPublica every Friday for a new quiz about our investigations.

"I think it's important that we keep in mind the progress that we have made, and remember the past and the struggles it took for equality in education to be achieved. But not to be excessively upset or bitter over it ... we should look to the future and ways that we can improve our schools and racial interactions." ‚Äî James Niiler, Northridge High School

Last fall, we asked high school students at two Tuscaloosa high schools - one integrated, one nearly all-black - to photograph their schools and tell us what they think about race and education. We will be sharing their stories - and yours - right here, in partnership with Michele Norris's #RaceCardProject. Read @nhannahjones' story and join the conversation at ProPublica.org/tuscaloosa.

Cameron Ford, a senior
at the University of Texas at Austin studying International Relations and Middle Eastern Studies, spent one summer interning with a bank and another interning at a non-profit that assists refugees ‚Äî both of which, she said, offered a more realistic view of the working world.
As an intern at a bank in Ft. Worth (making about $12 an hour, she says), she says she worked sometimes as a bank teller and sometimes did other work relating to advising or loans. In the non-profit position, which was unpaid, she said the small size of her office gave her an opportunity to interact directly with a lot of those coming in to seek help.
She doesn‚Äôt have strong feelings about unpaid internships, but she said she was ‚Äúmore blessed‚Äù than others might be, as she was able to depend on her parents for additional financial support while interning and also earned additional income through a part-time job.

Hannah Guernsey, a junior studying international relations and government at the University of Texas at Austin, interned with a local arm of a children‚Äôs advocacy organization. The position ended up giving her an in-depth look at the mechanisms of both non-profit and policy work.
Guernsey was unpaid, but, she said, make no mistake: her work was still meaningful: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do any pencil-pushing, I was never asked to get coffee.‚Äù She thinks unpaid internships can be ‚Äúelitist‚Äù in some cases because they tend to ‚Äúfavor people who can work for free‚Äù ‚Äî but for those working in non-profits, ‚Äúmost people who are doing it are not doing it to make money.‚Äù

Nazneen Rajani, a graduate computer science student at the University of Texas at Austin, said her internship with a San Diego-based technology company gave her a chance to expand on technical skills, as she helped to prepare software development for a product to launch in a few years, and introduced her to a more diverse workplace environment, as it was her first time working in the United States. (She said she pursued the paid internship for academic credit.)
An international student, Rajani said restrictions on the number of hours she could work were sometimes challenging ‚Äî she couldn‚Äôt work overtime, she says ‚Äî but her supervisors were generally understanding. She said the position offered plenty of support otherwise, too, providing assistance with travel, housing and other expenses as she relocated to a new city to pursue it.
Overall, her experience was valuable. ‚ÄúI got to meet a lot of people, learn a lot,‚Äù she said.
#ProjectIntern's destination today. Want to talk about your internship? Let @caseymcdermott know!

"I learned a lot of things not only about the business but about the corporate world in general, how to act in certain situations and how to address certain people."
Stephanie Reid, a sophomore studying English at Howard University, has interned with a medium-sized communications company in D.C. since January. As a finance intern, she spends time cataloging invoices and expense reports in addition to helping out with other tasks around the office. 
At first, she didn't know the position would be paid, but she said the compensation she receives has played a role in her decision to stick with the internship.

Brandon E. Patterson, a junior majoring in sociology with a minor in economics, said he learned a lot from his criminal defense internship with a D.C.-area law office this summer. His intern responsibilities included interviewing witnesses, reviewing police reports, drafting possible cross-examination questions and more. ‚ÄúI got pretty much a firsthand experience talking to and engaging with real people about their experiences with the law, with police,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄùThat was a really eye-opening experience for me.‚Äù The position was unpaid, and during his internship he worked on weekends and relied on additional family support.
We're at Howard University today, hoping to talk to more students about their intern stories for #ProjectIntern. Have one to share? Reach out to @caseymcdermott.

"I think often times we start internships with the thought that we‚Äôre not really valued, we‚Äôre not important, we‚Äôre just there to do the work that no one else wants to do ‚Äî but I found that in my past two summers of having internships that people really genuinely cared about who I was as a person, what I was interested in‚Ä¶" Lexie Kahn said both of her paid internships with nonprofit organizations (one through a leadership program in New York, another in D.C.) were rewarding, connecting her with professional mentors and a better sense of the field she hopes to pursue as a career.

"[My supervisor] tried to discourage me for most of the time that I was working there from working in the field." Danielle Buffa, a sophomore majoring in anthropology with a minor in GIS at the University of Maryland at College Park, says she tried not to let a former internship supervisor‚Äôs pessimistic view of her prospective field (archaeology) stand in the way of her career goals. 
While Buffa said it‚Äôd be nice to be paid, she thinks unpaid entry-level positions have a place in internships and archaeological field school work. (Positions that are full-time or where the intern is doing similar work to regular employees should at least provide transportation money, she said.)
"You don‚Äôt get money in my field," Buffa said. "You have to be one of the people who‚Äôs intrinsically motivated to be here."
#ProjectIntern is still in D.C. for a few days! First stop this week: University of Maryland. Reach out to @caseymcdermott if you're here and have an #intern story to share.

"As an undocumented student, you can‚Äôt apply for normal internships, for paid positions, because of your status." ‚ÄîMehdi Mahraoui, right. Mahraoui and Monica Sibri, students from the CUNY‚Äôs John Jay College of Criminal Justice and College of Staten Island, respectively, said they‚Äôve both encountered barriers to taking on paid internship positions because of their status as undocumented students. (Both are presidents of the DREAMers Clubs at their schools and were in Washington, D.C., Tuesday as part of the March for Immigrant Dignity and Respect.) While undocumented students face challenges seeking out internships, Sibri said unpaid positions can actually be beneficial, even if not financially: ‚ÄùUnpaid internships are really good for undocumented students because it gives them the opportunity to learn regardless of them getting paid or not paid.‚Äù

"Usually the tradeoff is that you‚Äôre getting paid with experience, and my unpaid internship experience was that I didn‚Äôt get enough work experience as I would‚Äôve wanted." Rafael Smith a senior in Communications Studies has had three internships: Two of those positions (with a radio station and the U.S. Virgin Islands legislature) were paid, and one with a record label in D.C. was unpaid. In his experience, he says his paid positions offered more hands-on experience than his unpaid one ‚Äî though overall, the experiences were formative in showing him that he was interested in the communications field. As a system, he says unpaid internships are ‚Äúclassist‚Äù and can shut out people who aren‚Äôt in a financial position to give up pay.

"I am fortunate in that I could probably get an unpaid internship and not need a job on top of that, but there are a lot of other people who could not afford to do that." A sophomore in the School of International Service at American University, Lindsay Wylie said she's conflicted on the value of unpaid internships ‚Äî though she does think that they create distinct disadvantages for low-income students. Recently, she said, she's weighed whether to take on an unpaid position with a government agency but found herself hesitating because it would require her to commit to three days of unpaid work (which would pose scheduling issues on top of her classes, especially because she's also double majoring in math) and an hour-long commute, which would also be additional money out-of-pocket. "Especially at AU, everyone has internships," Wylie says, "and it's definitely a necessary thing."

This guy didn't have any #internship stories to share, but it sounds like a lot of others at American University might. Are you one of them? Let @caseymcdermott know on Twitter. (Or email Casey.McDermott@propublica.org to share your story with #ProjectIntern.)

"Being an unpaid intern was definitely not something that held me back in this internship, because I knew that I was gaining real life experience that was invaluable." Stephanie Hsieh, studying Economics and Psychology at Brown University, said her unpaid internship (sometimes up to 52 hours a week) was worth it ‚Äî even if, she says, ‚ÄúThere were times when I felt like I should be getting paid for this.‚Äù She hopes the skills she gained in the process will help her in her internship search down the road ‚Äî for next summer, she‚Äôs aiming for something with a bigger company (and a paycheck).

"It's all about how your work translates to income for the company." Brown University senior Doreen St. Felix says her unpaid internship with a magazine wasn't particularly educational (she had two weeks to produce 100-word assignments, for example), but it was still helpful as professional experience to have on her resume. A nonfiction English major, she also had one other paid internship with local government and received funding from her school to complete the magazine internship and another unpaid position with a non-profit art organization. In general, she said unpaid internships tend to only "allow a certain class of kids" into those positions.

Brown University economics senior Nicole Grabel says her intern experience was a mixed bag. In one unpaid position with a NYC-area designer, she didn't learn much and spent a lot of time running errands. In a paid position with Nordstrom, though, she was given "a lot of real responsibility" and feedback about her work. Paying for intern labor's mutually beneficial, she says: "If they pay you, they want to be able to get something out of you."
#ProjectIntern's in Providence for the day! In the area and have an #internship story to share? Let @caseymcdermott know.

Would you work an internship with midnight to 8 a.m. hours? Emerson College senior Bailey Lawless did in 2012, working about three times a week for $20 an hour as a sound intern on a BBC television show. "It got kind of lonely" sometimes if he was working alone, and tasks (as one of the "middlemen" prepping audio files between parts of the production process) weren‚Äôt always exciting, but he said he was OK with the arrangement. He picked up valuable technical skills, he said, and probably would've still taken the position if it had been unpaid.

"If my internship weren‚Äôt paid, I would still do it." Michael O‚ÄôBrien, a freshman at Harvard University who plans to pursue Social Studies, just started an internship with an on-campus center for the environment. So far, the gig (a few hours a week, and paid) has been educational and manageable with his schedule.

"...But I wish I'd been paid. And having friends in the STEM field, it's definitely hard to watch them, their internships tend to be very well-paid, and people in the non-profit field don't really get that much love in the monetary sense." Abigail Burman is a second-year History student at the University of Oxford. To eventually find a career that‚Äôs ‚Äúsomething save the world-y,‚Äù Burman‚Äôs taken on unpaid internships with non-profits and political campaigns.

"The experience really allowed me to see what I learned in class actually in action." ‚Äî Anna Brewster, a student at Harvard School of Public Health, estimates that she‚Äôs held about six or seven internships mostly in the health field. (All but one of them, for a smaller nonprofit where she was only working part-time, were compensated.)

‚ÄúIt opened my eyes to how cruel and taxing the actual internship market can be, and how a lot of students, they go into‚Ä¶ looking for internships but they don‚Äôt always find something in their field, and what they do find they realize is unpaid or pays very little to nothing. and they still have to do it because, you know, they just need the experience." ‚Äî Arnab Tarafder, a computer science senior at Columbia University, reflects on what he learned as an intern with a non-profit and an independent film office. (He was paid, though he says "very little.")

"Liberal arts college definitely can be very deceiving because you‚Äôre kind of stuck in this bubble of academia, and it‚Äôs really interesting to see how things function and how the knowledge you learn at an institution like this does or does not translate to the real world." Barnard College sophomore Mariam Elnozahy's had three internships, a mix of unpaid and paid positions.

"I'm the kind of person who really likes to learn... and if I get the opportunity to do so ‚Äî to do an internship, whether I'm being paid or not ‚Äî I'm probably going to do it. Because, I don't know, I don't find that demeaning. I do find it unethical not to be paid, but in a sense I know that I can get so much more out of it than just being paid, like, minimum wage." Christian Scibetta, now a sophomore at NYU, says his high school internship with a fashion company in London was the kind of experience he "can't put a price on."

"What is the one word or phrase that you'd use to describe your internship experience?" "First, slavery. Secondly, unfortunate... 'Slavery' because I was literally working for free. That is the crux of slavery: free labor... 'Unfortunate' because I was unfortunate enough to be a slave to these people." Luis Alvarez, a junior at City College of New York, said all of his internships (in the culinary and music industries) have been unpaid.

"People who don't have the same privileges that I had are not able to do unpaid internships." Peter Sterne's a senior at Columbia University studying anthropology. After three unpaid internships with media organizations, he started a crowdsourcing project (WhoPaysInterns.Tumblr.com) to keep track of compensation within the journalism industry.

Meet New School junior Kelsey Salyer: She created an internship with her school's dining services to study labor practices in its supply chain, on the condition that she'd be paid. "It would just be ridiculous if I have this internship to make sure people aren't getting exploited while being exploited myself." #ProjectIntern
